review.title: Tramp Ship Scheduling Problem with Berth Allocation Considerations and Time-dependent Constraints
review.abstract: This work presents a model for the Tramp Ship Scheduling problem including berth allocation considerations, motivated by a real case of a shipping company. The aim is to determine the travel schedule for each vessel considering multiple docking and multiple time windows at the berths. This work is innovative due to the consideration of both spatial and temporal attributes during the scheduling process. The resulting model is formulated as a mixed-integer linear programming problem, and a heuristic method to deal with multiple vessel schedules is also presented. Numerical experimentation is performed to highlight the benefits of the proposed approach and the applicability of the heuristic. Conclusions and recommendations for further research are provided.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Maritime shipping accounts for more than 80% of foreign trade, and is positioned as the most relevant means of transport in world trade. The world fleet has experienced continuous growth with an annual increase of 4.1% in 2013, reaching a total of 1.69 billion dwt (working tonnage) in January 2014. Shipping companies are constantly striving to achieve economies of scale in order to reduce transport costs, which are strongly influenced by fuel costs. Therefore, the planning and planning of routes is critical.The ship planning problem, taking into account berth allocation, has been highlighted as a promising area of research both operationally and economically.? sections.heading: 2 Related works
sections.text: This work is related to two known problems, the Ship Scheduling Problem and the Berth Assignment Problem (BAP). The integration of these two intertwined problems has recently been identified as a promising area of research in both operational and economic terms [1, 2]. In this regard, the work in [9] proposes an integrated model for ship planning and berth allocation, motivated by the case of shipping lines with their own terminals. In a follow-up paper [10], the authors include transhipment. Both work represent a case study of a feeder service company operating in the Pearl River Delta region. A discreet arrangement of each port terminal with time restrictions is considered, but a ship cannot visit the same terminal more than once during the planning horizon. The problem dealt with in this work concerns the transport of palletized perishable cargo (fruits) during the fruit season.

sections.heading: 3 Problem definition
sections.text: Consider a number of contracts C with due date, destination and cargo to be fulfilled by the shipping company. There are a number of port terminals for the loading of cargo on ships. Each port terminal has a number of berths with different draught capacities, which limit the amount of cargo that can be loaded on ships. In addition, berths have a variety of time windows in which ships can be moored. One consideration of the problem is that the cargo in a ship cannot be fully loaded if it is not profitable. If a cargo is not fully loaded, compensation will be paid to its customer. Also, the design of the ship should be evaluated when setting the timetable. The design of a ship corresponds to the maximum displacement at full load. Ship displacement occurs when there is a change in the vertical distance between the waterline and the bottom of the hull when the pallets are loaded on the ship.

sections.heading: 6 Solution Approach
sections.text: The MILP model in this work becomes more difficult to solve as the number of ships increases. All decision variables and limitations of the process are indexed by the number of ships. In addition, restrictions (9) - (10) are made on scheduling linkages between ships and ships, while the schedules of ships cannot be determined separately from each other. Therefore, a heuristic decomposition method has been developed to efficiently resolve instances involving multiple ships. As shown in Fig. 2, the method is divided into two phases. Phase 1 quickly determines an initial schedule for each ship, whereas Phase 2 attempts to improve / verify these schedules while not spending too much time. sections.heading: 8 Conclusions and Further Research
sections.text: This work leads to an optimization of the model, which deals with the problem of trampolines and takes into account the availability of berths. It is formulated as a mixed-holistic linear problem and performs the assignment of berth windows to ships in which cargo is loaded, the routes of ships with the possibility of docking several times at the same or other berth, and the coordination of ships operating at the same time at one berth. Furthermore, the model takes into account the limitations of berths in terms of water depth or draught capacity. These limitations have not previously been addressed by the problem of berth allocation to the trampolar scheme. The proposed approach provides a decision support tool for the trampolar shipping company. The current planning activities are carried out manually by operational planners who deal with several difficulties in finding a feasible plan.
